entry.et: Middle English yelwe, yelow, from Old English geolu; akin to Old High German gelo yellow, Latin helvus light bay, Greek chlōros greenish yellow, Sanskrit hari yellowish

def.dt: :of the color yellow
:become yellowish through age, disease, or discoloration :sallow
:having a yellowish or light brown complexion or skin
:featuring sensational or scandalous items or ordinary news sensationally distorted yellow journalism
:mean cowardly
:something yellow or marked by a yellow color: as
:a person having yellowish or light brown skin
:the yolk of an egg
:a color whose hue resembles that of ripe lemons or sunflowers or is that of the portion of the spectrum lying between green and orange
:a pigment or dye that colors yellow
:jaundice
:any of several plant diseases caused especially by phytoplasmas and marked by yellowing of the foliage and stunting
:to become or turn yellow
:to make yellow :give a yellow tinge or color to yellowed by time
river 3396 miles (5464 kilometers) N China flowing from Kunlun Mountains in Qinghai E into Bo Hai
:a humor believed in medieval physiology to be secreted by the liver and to cause irascibility
:a large birch (Betula alleghaniensis syn. B. lutea) of chiefly eastern North America with thin lustrous gray or yellow bark forming plates with ragged edges in older trees
:its strong hard dark brown to reddish-brown wood
:mean contemptible
:of or relating to opposition to trade unionism or a labor union
:an employment contract in which a worker disavows membership in and agrees not to join a labor union in order to get a job
:any of several plant diseases of cereal grasses (as oats and barley), onions, potatoes, tomatoes, or tobacco that are characterized by yellowing and stunting and are caused by viruses
